name: Puri
history: Puri is a traditional Indian bread and a popular dish across the Indian subcontinent. It has a rich history and is often associated with festive occasions, religious ceremonies, and family gatherings.
description: Puri is a deep-fried Indian bread made from unleavened whole wheat flour dough. It puffs up into a light, crispy, and golden-brown delicacy when fried. Puris are commonly served with savory curries or sweet dishes like halwa.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Mix whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead to form a firm dough. Let it rest for 10 minutes.

instructions.title: Roll and Fry the Puris
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Roll each ball into a small, flat circle. Heat oil in a deep frying pan. Fry each puri until it puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the hot puris with a side dish like potato curry, chana masala, or sweet halwa.

tips: The oil should be hot enough to make the puris puff up immediately.
Roll the puris evenly for uniform cooking.
variations: Add spices like carom seeds (ajwain) to the dough for a different flavor.
Make stuffed puris with fillings like spiced lentils or mashed potatoes.

storage.shelfLife: Puris are best enjoyed fresh and are not typically stored.
storage.instructions: If necessary, store in an airtight container for a few hours.

reheatingInstructions: Reheating is not recommended as it affects the texture.
presentationTips: Serve on a platter lined with absorbent paper to remove excess oil.
Garnish with fresh herbs or side salads for a colorful presentation.
